snippet: States, cities and counties are giving up more than $80 billion a year to attract or keep companies and the jobs they provide. But officials and governments rarely track how many jobs follow, and many do not know the value of all their awards.
abstract: States, cities and counties across United States are giving up more than $80 billion per year in incentives to attract or keep companies and jobs they provide, but officials and governments rarely track how many jobs are created or saved; analysis of incentive spending reveals that corporations have exploited fears to create high-stakes bazaar where they pit local officials against one another to get most lucrative packages. (Series: United States of Subsidies)

byline.contributor: Lisa Schwartz and Ramsey Merritt contributed research.

lead_paragraph: States, cities and counties are giving up more than $80 billion a year to attract or keep companies and the jobs they provide. But officials and governments rarely track how many jobs follow, and many do not know the value of all their awards.

headline.main: As Companies Seek Tax Deals, Governments Pay High Price
headline.print_headline: The Empty Promise of Tax Incentives
